reviewText:
Garfield Kart is a racing game developed by Gravity Europe releasing on PC in November 2013. The game has also been released on Nintendo 3DS previously as well.

We have all come to know what to expect from kart racing games from the likes of Mario Kart in the past. Most kart games that have come out to try and rival Mario Kart have often fallen flat on their face. Prior to playing Garfield, I had played another kart racing game on Steam, Coffin Dodgers and sadly that didn’t live up to the mark. Garfield Kart is almost an identical game to that of Coffin Dodgers.

Gameplay is going to be simple when it comes to kart racing, simply beat your opponents in the race around a circuit. There are 16 different courses to race around with 8 different powerups to collect around the circuits too. The game’s tutorial is back to front when it comes to explaining the controls; whether they did it with a different controller in mind I am not sure, but the controls on an Xbox controller were the complete opposite to shown on the screen. Garfield Kart has three different game modes to play, Grand Prix, Single Race and Time Trial. Grand Prix is the more structured part of the game, where you take part in 4 or 5 races at a time in a league, depending on where you finish in the races will determine how many points you get. Single Race is more like the “free mode”, whilst you can gain money from competing in races here; there aren’t any huge rewards for winning. Time Trial is what you would expect from a Kart Racing game; nothing too exciting and certainly the least interesting of the three modes.

There is one final game mode which is where Garfield does something a little different to the rest of the Kart Games on Steam. A daily challenge mode is included, complete the set task and you will get a reward at the end of it. This is a really easy way to gather better upgrades for your car without having the need to grind out money by replaying previous tournaments.

Graphically, Garfield Karts looks really nice. It looks like one of the cartoons, with some really nice modelling, textures and animations on show. The game’s environments are all very nicely designed as well. The sound effects do let the game down a little bit; it can sometimes seem too quiet at times. Your engine noise can almost seem too quiet for it to seem realistic which something which felt really odd when playing is. The sound track is really catchy though.

Garfield Kart has three levels of difficulties. Whilst you are not able to choose the difficulties per race, you choose which bracket of difficulty race to take part in; 50cc, 100cc and 150cc.  Obviously the higher the number the more powerful the rest of your opponents cars will be. In order to even be competitive in the 100cc and 150cc bracket, you will have to completely upgrade your car using the upgrade system; you are able to purchase items for your car which will improve three criteria of performance, speed, handling and power. You will also be able to choose from a selection of helmets which will also grant you a specific bonus for individual power ups which you can collect. Whilst I really liked the upgrade system, it does feel very much like a grind to unlock items as you have to replay previously won competitions in order to get anywhere close to being able to buy anything. I would have personally liked to have seen a reduction in the price set on the items so you aren’t forced to replay already played content if you don’t want to.  The daily challenge mode helps with this, but only if you play the game in small doses.

I have been playing for over an hour so far and I have just completed the first bracket of races whilst also taking part in the daily challenge and a couple of time trials. There is easily another 3 or 4 hours of content from this game. Sadly the game will have very little staying power and I will more than likely not play the game again after completing the three stages of difficulty. With the lack of any multiplayer mode, the developers have really shot themselves in the foot of making game out of a genre which is so perfectly crafted for any type of multiplayer action.

As the Steam page says for this game, there is only partial controller support for this game. The gameplay itself works well with a control, however you have to navigate menus with your mouse, making a bit awkward to play on a couch setup.  There is a wide selection of resolutions to play on, right the way up to 4k, with minimal graphic options to change.

To sum up, Garfield Kart is purely an OK game. There aren’t any glaringly obvious negative points; it’s just not going to blow your socks off with exciting game play moments and hilarious local multiplayer. The only thing that resembles Garfield in this game is the character models; there is no story, no voice acting, and nothing else that makes this game any different to a generic kart racer. Luckily the game is priced low at £5, 59, and for that price you will get some enjoyment out of it, just don’t go into it expecting all the bells and whistles of Mario Kart.  I’ve marked it down as a 3 on my scale, it’s not the best game, but it certainly isn’t a bad game either. If you can get it less than the sale price, you will want to consider checking it out for an hour or two of action.

Once upon a time there was this orange cat that ripped off Heathcliff like nobody's business. Then it got its own movie starring Bill Murray in a catsuit, which was funny because Bill played Pete from the Ghostbusters. Then when the Ghostbusters had a cartoon show, the voice of Garfield's cartoon show was also the voice of Pete. No one liked the movie, not even with Jennifer Love Hewitt in it and she can sell icecream to a dying man in the arctic who has no mouth or hands and he's trapped in a block of ice.

So with Heathfield's popularity it was only a matter of time before he got his own video game. Sure he had other video games, but this one would be good. The one to compete against the greatest kart racing game in existence, Crash Team Racing on the PS1. The men that forged this game would need the ultimate engine to play the game on that would power the game across several different platforms such as mobile devices, the 3DS and the PC itself. That game engine is Unity 3D, the engine used by other popular games like Walden and the Werewolf!

Once they had their game, they filled it with food items. Candy for weapons that consist of pies, lasagna and pillows. We've all had that dream where we're eating a really big marsh mellow and when we wake up there's no pillow on the bed and we burp feathers. This will be that game. A game so thrilling that the pillow will put all the other drivers to sleep, letting us slip by unnoticed. Lasagna will be made of nuclear energy that will let us boost ahead.

I say let us this and let us that meaning you. The buyer of this game. You will be that us, because there's no multiplayer in this game coop or otherwise. I mean online or local. That's what I mean.

Garfield Kart will be a great game for kids. All children love Garfield and they have since he was invented way back in 1910. A game so great for kids that powersliding becomes a tough as nails art to master and necessary for survival in 100 CC races because 50 CC is so dull and slow I found myself dozing with every turn before someone hit me with a diamond. I'm looking at you Odie...

Eight characters have been shoveled into this masterpiece that I put now with my wallet photo of Mona Lisa. Classics like Jen, who is someone's girlfriend. I assume played by Jennifer Love Hewitt, who becomes the most overpowered character in the game as ever man, woman and cat stares her way as she drives by using perfume and lust as a weapon, jumping over bridges, rolling over hills, slamming down on the dirt roads that you will drive over again and again on your way to victory over those that compete for Jen's love.

This game is great because it incorporates two control schemes people love at the same time. There is a mouse control scheme for the menu and a 360 controls for the driving, but not 360 controls for the menu or mouse controls for the driving. This lets me get my third hand playing the game as well. The game has the controls backward when displaying the tutorial. The left trigger goes backward, the right trigger goes forward. Its all part of the challenge the game brings. There are two buttons for forward attacking and behind attacking too, but there's only one button for hopping when it could have been hopping left or hopping right like Super Mario Kart had twenty years ago.

The sixteen tracks are all fun and interesting. Four of them take place at the airport. Another few take place in egypt, some are in the snow with snowmen and pine trees. Others take place on a farm where cows live, but there are no cows, because Garfield loves to eat things. That is why there are no cows. Garfield and other characters have eaten so much that they are the same size and height as Jon who is a human, but Garfield is Bill Murray. Odie is played by Rhea Pearlman (great aunt of Ron Pearlman and Danny DiVito's wife) and Sheldon (Cooper?) in this game and it must have cost a lot of money to get the celebrity voice acting. I'm just kidding there isn't celebrity voice acting, just bad voice acting that you get to hear a lot.

Before each race you get to buy what cheats you want to use. These cheats cost money, but not micropayments. Instead you need to grind for the cash you need to buy stuff. Playing the same races over and over before you can buy that chick magnet car you always wanted, but Nermal drives. Cheats really help you compete in the 155 CC races so you can finish in 6th and final place a few seconds less than you would normally.

This game comes with a stop watch, because during the races, they don't keep time for you. You need to do that yourself. With a stop watch. I then write down my best times for the grand prix mode so I have them always. There is a time trial, but why would I ever use that to keep track of time when I'm only racing against a UFO? That's right Garfield Kart has UFOs and so many of them that they should be identified by now. You race against one in the time trial, which makes it more of a race with an actual time instead of the real races with no time. Then you also find them in the real races as a way to crash the first place racer, so its always best to be in second place until the end, where winning matters. You play to win.

I will recommend it to all my friends no matter what their age. We all know and love Garfield. He is the best cat and Felix would end up in 6th place if he raced Garfield, because Garfield can drive a truck in this game but Felix can just sack race. Garfield is a great game and will continue to be the standard bearer for Bill Murray and Jennifer Love Hewitt games. Someone should make a sequel with Alvin & the Chipmunks.

reviewText:
Who we are is not just what we appear to be on the outside. When you think of Garfield, you may think of a lazy cat lounging next to some of that sweet, sweet lasagna and otherwise not caring about a single thing that doesn't involve naptime. However, what you believed Garfield to be will be crushed in this harrowing tale of smashing our limiters and truly becoming who we are behind the mask that society gives us to live by, Garfield Kart.

In Garfield Kart, you play as any one of the Garfield cast in thrilling and chaotic go-kart rides through insane and strategically-involved tracks everywhere from Egypt to industrial Zimbabwe. After racing you can customize your racer with special items such as hats, spoilers and new karts. The items you buy effect your driver performance, and some item sets are made specifically for a certain driver. Stacking a full set of driver-specific items onto the driver they were meant for makes you very powerful, and in the world of Garfield Kart, you either get good or die hard.

During your gameplay you may wonder why some characters act out of place according to the setting of the original comics they come from. The nurse (Liz) turns from helpful hand of medicine into a competitive matriarch who crushes the enemy beneath her iron go-kart, and even Garfield himself acts out of his usual lazy character. All of the people in Garfield Kart seem to be only alike to their comic counterparts only in appearance (and even that is questionable once the hats start rolling in). How could this be? You may wonder to yourself how these characters could be so unlike their original bases, until you realize one day that they are not different at all.

Garfield Kart isn't just a tale of a friendly competition between some friends (and also that stupid grey cat who keeps hitting me with aliens RIGHT BEFORE I FINISH THE FINAL LAP IN FIRST NERMAL I WILL END YOU), but the tale of self-actualization and the breaking of societal norms through sport. Garfield himself abandons the mask so forced upon him by society to become his true self. The character customization store is just another way to self actualize, with every set of items for each character representing who they really are in the dark. When you finish a set of items for a character, you successfuly break society's pre-determined path for this character and allow them to be themselves once more. This is also why the completed sets make your characters much more powerful.

Garfield Kart is a triumph of the gaming industry, and is more akin to a work of art that focuses on the trials and tribulations the people of today go through to become their true selves. I think we can all take a page out of Garfield Kart's book, and strive not only to be the best we can be, but to also become who we know we are deep inside.

Thank you.

reviewText:
As a cart racing game this one is pretty generic but perfectly fine, however the PC port is a disaster. No matter what graphical preset I selected or resolution, this game would drop to sub 30 FPS on a consistent basis. Some tracks would see single digit FPS drops in places. And it's not just the low FPS, it's the insane dips and spikes. If you have a good PC, in the span of 15 seconds you will go from 100+ FPS down to 10 FPS. The framerate is all over the place, making the karts impossible to control at times. And the specs given are completely off base with the games actual demands. My PC slaughters the recommended specs. I have an 8 core CPU Overclocked to 4.5 ghz, an R9 270X with 2gbs VRAM and 16 gbs of Ram. I can run nearly every high end modern game at 1080p 60fps on High/Ultra settings. I can't even maintain a solid 30 on the lowest graphical preset with Garfield Kart, so the idea that a dual core 2ghz CPU, and 256 mbs of VRAM could run this thing, is laughable. So unless you have an insane PC with a Free-sync or G-Sync monitor to negate the massive dips and spikes, you might want to steer clear of this one. It's a shame that the port is unplayable, because the actual game was pretty good.

Update

I forgot to mention the fact that in Grand Prix mode, you cannot advance races in fullscreen, you are forced to play windowed.

reviewText:
Garfield Kart is the third title in the massively popular Garfield series, following 2008's Garfield: Devasta Coastline and 2011's Garfield: Tides of Darkness. Garfield Kart follows the titular character 'Garfield' and his crew of ragtag mercenaries as they continue their search for the buried treasure of the legendary pirate captain Orion Baskerville. This particular game takes place on the arid desert planet of Boralia, and see's our heroes utilising vehicles to cross the massive landscapes. The driving controls are tight and responsive, and the ground combat, a mix of Batman Arkham melee and Gears of War-esque gunplay, works well, with the bosses spiking difficulty later in the game. The story is enjoyable and kept me interested for its 20+ hour duration. Plenty of sidequests and diversions in the game world to keep players interested long after completing the campaign.

The sound design is absoloutely top-notch, from the report of gun, rev of an engine or blood curdling squeal of an undead aboriginal pirate. Guest voice actors include Michael Rosen, Johan Hegg and Alexis Texas.

The game runs perfectly at 24+ FPS on Virtual Machine running Windows 95 with 64mb RAM and 1.2Mgz processor.

My only criticism is that the controller support is a bit dodgy, the only button prompts i could get to show up on screen appeared to be from a Neo-Geo pocket X.

Overall, 9.75/10 would definetly play for 104 hours  again

reviewText: Looking for that purr-fect kart racer? Look no further than Garfield Kart! If you're a fan of a certain lasagna-loving, Monday-hating tubby fella (and who isn't!) then you owe it to yourself to check this little under-the-radar gem out. Sure, the production value isn't quite up to par with that of another well-known kart racer that, let's be honest, is becoming a little long in the tooth, but the sheer amount of enthusiasm the developers have for our favorite feline franchise is evident in every nook and cranny of this lovingly crafted title. Beautiful 1080p graphics and a whimsical color pallete bring Garfield's world to fluid, 60-fps life and it's a truly sublime experience to finally race through the environments that Jim Davis let us escape to for so many years. The power up items are all clever nods to the comic - Garfield's favorite pasta dish (if you're a true fan, enough said on what this could be!) allows him and his friends to perform heart-pounding, tooth gritting boosts to the karts - as well as to the player's heart rate as the adrenaline starts to surge! The famous (or infamous?...) spring is also present, enabling players to finally re-enact all of their favorite spring-related antics from the comic strip. Character and kart customization options allow for endless replayablility, plus playing dress-up with our furry friends is a joy in and of itself (ever wish you could just slap a chef's hat on Odie? Wish no more, your prayers have been answered!).\n\nI could go on, but hopefully if you've read this far I've already convinced you to give this game a shot. If you have even the slightest interest in Garfield, Kart racing, or video games in general then don't let this one pass you by!
